message:
Being somebody who is currently trying to "formally educate" himself on the subject, I feel that mentioning explicitly the synchronous blocking behavior of Task.Result property would have clarified a lot. I read most of the referred answered questions and most all of the people having the problem were expecting a magic to happen and return the result from the task - a magic similar to what async and await give us, hiding the complexities of CPS programming from us.  

Here's what MSDN has to say about Task.Result property:  
(from here [http://msdn.microsoft.com/e...](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd321468.aspx) "http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd321468.aspx)")  
Remarks  
The get accessor for this property ensures that the asynchronous operation is complete before returning.
